articles.headline: In Myanmar, Government Reforms Win Over Some Skeptics
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will arrive on Wednesday as a show of support for Myanmar’s transformation to nascent democracy.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will arrive on Wednesday as a show of support for Myanmar’s transformation to nascent democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The waves of change sweeping Myanmar are trickling down to the broken sidewalks and potholed streets of this dilapidated city.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Settles Privacy Issue at Facebook
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission announced a proposed settlement that compels the company to obtain consent before making changes to users’ privacy settings.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission announced a proposed settlement that compels the company to obtain consent before making changes to users’ privacy settings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Accusing Facebook of engaging in “unfair and deceptive” practices, the federal government on Tuesday announced a broad settlement that requires the company to respect the privacy wishes of its users and subjects it to regular privacy audits for the next 20 years.

articles.headline: A New Shot at Mortgage Relief
articles.snippet: The two-year-old Home Affordable Refinance Program would double in size to assist about 900,000 more homeowners.
articles.abstract: The two-year-old Home Affordable Refinance Program would double in size to assist about 900,000 more homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like millions of other homeowners, William D. Compton would like to refinance his mortgage so that he pays less each month for his three-bedroom house in Gulf Breeze, Fla. With the savings, he figures he could afford a few extra movies and restaurant dinners or he could buy a new stove and brakes for his car, purchases he has postponed because finances are so tight.

articles.headline: Facing Generic Lipitor Rivals, Pfizer Battles to Protect Its Cash Cow
articles.snippet: Pfizer’s aggressive strategy may offer lessons for drug makers facing similar losses of patent protection for other blockbuster drugs over the next few years.
articles.abstract: Pfizer’s aggressive strategy may offer lessons for drug makers facing similar losses of patent protection for other blockbuster drugs over the next few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last year, Pfizer has been laying the groundwork to combat the looming competition against Lipitor, forging deals with insurers, pharmacy benefit managers and patients to meet or beat the price of its generic replacements.

articles.headline: Gingrich Gave Push to Clients, Not Just Ideas
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich is adamant that he is not a lobbyist, but in the eight years since he started his health care consultancy, he has made millions of dollars while helping companies promote their services.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich is adamant that he is not a lobbyist, but in the eight years since he started his health care consultancy, he has made millions of dollars while helping companies promote their services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newt Gingrich is adamant that he is not a lobbyist, but rather a visionary who traffics in ideas, not influence. But in the eight years since he started his health care consultancy, he has made millions of dollars while helping companies promote their services and gain access to state and federal officials.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Cain, Support Eroding, Weighs Dropping Bid
articles.snippet: The spirit of defiance that characterized the Herman Cain campaign after accusations of sexual harassment arose seemed to be slipping away amid a report of an affair.
articles.abstract: The spirit of defiance that characterized the Herman Cain campaign after accusations of sexual harassment arose seemed to be slipping away amid a report of an affair.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leading conservative voices who have come to Herman Cain’s defense began backing away on Tuesday as he acknowledged that he was reassessing his Republican presidential bid, uncertain that he could withstand a report of an extramarital affair after accusations of sexual harassment and stumbling foreign policy responses.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: Ratings Firms Misread Signs of Greek Woes
articles.snippet: Critics say Moody’s Investors Service and other ratings agencies missed signs of trouble in Greece, now the center of the crisis in the euro zone.
articles.abstract: Critics say Moody’s Investors Service and other ratings agencies missed signs of trouble in Greece, now the center of the crisis in the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a stern pronouncement, Moody’s Investors Service this week warned of rising prospects for multiple defaults by countries in the euro zone and credit rating downgrades of nations across Europe if leaders should fail to resolve the spreading debt crisis.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: 6 Central Banks Act to Buy Time in Europe Crisis
articles.snippet: Six central banks, including the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, said they had agreed to lower the cost of borrowing dollars for foreign banks.
articles.abstract: Six central banks, including the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, said they had agreed to lower the cost of borrowing dollars for foreign banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve and other major central banks moved on Wednesday to help foreign banks more easily borrow and lend money, seeking to forestall a breakdown of global financial markets and giving Europe more time to wrestle with its debts. The latest round of interventions by central banks, including the expansion of an existing Fed program that lets foreign banks borrow dollars at a low interest rate, reflects growing concerns that Europe’s financial problems are hampering growth.

articles.headline: Banks Act, Stocks Surge and Skeptics See a Pattern
articles.snippet: Market indexes gained more than 4 percent Wednesday after central banks acted to contain the debt crisis in the euro zone. But similar rallies in the last 18 months have quickly withered.
articles.abstract: Market indexes gained more than 4 percent Wednesday after central banks acted to contain the debt crisis in the euro zone. But similar rallies in the last 18 months have quickly withered.
articles.lead_paragraph: A move announced by central bankers on Wednesday to contain the European debt crisis resulted in euphoria in global stock markets, but it also prompted skeptics to wonder: will this time be different?
